faqs.question: What are the minimum insurance requirements for trucking in Georgia?
faqs.answer: For intrastate carriers, Georgia's statutory minimums are $100,000 per person / $300,000 per accident in bodily injury liability. However, most brokers and shippers require $750,000-$1,000,000 regardless of state minimums. Interstate carriers need a minimum of $750,000 filed with FMCSA.

faqs.question: Do I need separate authority for intrastate-only trucking in Georgia?
faqs.answer: Yes. If you only operate within Georgia, you register under the Georgia Intrastate Motor Carrier (GIMC) program through the Georgia Department of Public Safety. You'll need a USDOT number with a 'GA' suffix displayed on your vehicle.

faqs.question: How fast can I get a quote?
faqs.answer: Same day for most operations. Complex risks (hazmat, port drayage, specialized cargo) may take 24-48 hours to shop properly.

faqs.question: What insurance do I need for Port of Savannah container hauling?
faqs.answer: Port/drayage operations typically need Auto Liability ($750K+), Cargo Insurance, Physical Damage, and Trailer Interchange coverage for chassis and container swaps.

faqs.question: Can I get same-day proof of insurance for my Georgia trucking company?
faqs.answer: Yes. RMS issues Certificates of Insurance (COIs) in 5 minutes. Federal filings (BMC-91/91X) take about 10 minutes.

faqs.question: Do I need PUCO authority if I only haul within Ohio?
faqs.answer: Yes - if you're a for-hire carrier hauling point-to-point within Ohio, you need a CPCN from PUCO. Private carriers and interstate-only operations are exempt.

faqs.question: Can RMS file my Form E with PUCO?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. When we bind your policy, we file your Form E electronically with PUCO and your BMC-91X with FMCSA. Both filings happen within minutes.

faqs.question: What insurance do I need to run I-75 between Ohio and Michigan?
faqs.answer: Since you're crossing state lines, you need interstate authority (USDOT + MC number) with a minimum $750,000 liability. No PUCO needed for interstate work.

faqs.question: What happens if my trucking insurance lapses in Ohio?
faqs.answer: PUCO will suspend your intrastate authority until updated proof is filed. FMCSA will revoke your interstate authority. Either way, you cannot legally haul.

faqs.question: Do I need PA PUC authority if I'm crossing state lines?
faqs.answer: No. If you're hauling interstate (origin or destination outside PA), you only need federal FMCSA authority (USDOT + MC number). PA PUC is only for intrastate - both pickup and delivery within Pennsylvania.

faqs.question: How much does Pennsylvania trucking insurance cost?
faqs.answer: For new authorities in Pennsylvania, expect $8,000-$19,000/year for a single truck with $750K liability. PA rates reflect the high-traffic corridors and urban density around Philadelphia and the Lehigh Valley.

faqs.question: How fast can I get a quote from RMS?
faqs.answer: Same day for most operations. Complex risks (hazmat, port work, specialized cargo) may take 24-48 hours to shop properly.

faqs.question: What's the difference between Form E and a certificate of insurance?
faqs.answer: Form E is the official PUC filing - it goes directly from your insurer to the PA PUC as proof of coverage. A certificate of insurance (COI) is what you give to brokers and shippers. You need both for PA intrastate work. RMS handles the Form E filing and issues COIs in 5 minutes.

faqs.question: I'm hauling out of the Port of Philadelphia. Any special requirements?
faqs.answer: Port work may require additional coverage depending on your cargo. Refrigerated loads have special weight permits (up to 107,500 lbs in the Philadelphia area). RMS knows PhilaPort operations and will make sure your coverage matches what the terminals and brokers require.
